comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] The greenest green ever seen!!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I remember the late 60s/early 70s, when the buses were cream over blue, like this one: but I don't remember any petrol green buses like that one!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/30369211@N00]  Are you showing your age Niall? That was the good old CIE green we all grew up to love and admire!  The two young lads in the pinstripe suit jackets is an interesting sight!  Not likely to be school blazers as they tended to be solid colours but may be the remains of auld dacency in the form of Confirmation suits being worn out before they grew out if you know what I mean.  Kids in 1959 could dress quite formally once they got to 14 or thereabouts.  Portobello is just down the road from St. Mary's College and the lads may be from there but never with pin stripe blazers???

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] And yet there it is, larger than life and twice as green! I wonder is there any way it was a tour bus, rather than a "normal" city bus?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03]  No Carol, all buses were green until the big change to the blue and cream for the city buses that Niall illustrates. Later they also coloured them a manure orange if you recall those!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Quote from The Classic Irish Buses website: R726 had been transferred to Clontarf in 1965, and as can be seen was badly in need of a repaint from its original green livery to the then new blue and cream, by this time green buses were becoming a rarity in the CIE fleet.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I remember the orange ones, and then they went two-tone green, but I don't know if any of the old buses like this one with no doors ever went orange.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Seriously? Were they all that green before the cream topped ones came in? That colour'd damage your retinas, particularly on a sunny day...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] I beg your purddn, that was classic Irish green, the best colour FOR your retinas, sunny day or otherwise!  And yes, all of the CIE Bus fleet both urban and rural were that lovely patriotic shade of green!  Happy St. Patricks day to all!

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.author: 90124154@N00
comment._content: Consider that relative to other colors, Kodachrome's greens were rather muted and subdued (disregarding whatever Paul Simon sang about the "greens of summer")

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: The green livery was great, personally I don't think they've managed anything better since, the orange tan era might have been the worst! You can just see the flying snail logo on its side too.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: You can see a better example of the "actual" colouring at www.flickr.com/photos/be216cd1/6576449365/

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/22919290@N08] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] The colour is affected to some extent also by the bright sunshine that was obviously present on the day!  I agree FS that the livery was really great and nothing since has come close.  That's a great example Bill, thank you.

comment.author: 58930216@N04
comment._content: Dublin's buses were basically green between 1945 and 1960 something, then they went to blue and cream. In the 1970's they went tan (or orange as people commonly think). Then in the early 1980's, with the arrival of the Shannon built Bombardiers they went back to a green scheme once more. Then during the late 1990's they went to the blue & cream livery again though the cream was different and there was an orange stripe too. Then in the 2000's they went to the current scheme of yellow and blue, with some in green for special duties. Not forgetting the white of the Wedding buses........

comment.author: 58930216@N04
comment._content: And of course, 37M was similar to the one used in one of the RTE Waterways series presented by Dick Warner!

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/30369211@N00] Yep Naill, remember the black & cream liveries well but I believe we are not old enough to remember the green busses.

comment.author: 75752622@N07
comment._content:
Love the R class Titans but as a child of the 80's I grew up with Bombardiers & orange Atlanteans in my early years so missed out on them, I wish some of them(apart from those preserved) had of survived long enough to be passed onto Dublin in use on heritage routes similar to London routemasters . 
Also good to see Christy Birds antiques shop on the top left corner of the picture is still going strong 53 years later.
